title: What types of business problems can be solved using statistics? - Quora

response.answer_text: I can give you a specific problem that my company has experienced that has been solved with a subset of statistics. We were founded after our CEO realized that anyone who employs remote teams (and for this purpose we can include outsourced employees) relinquishes a lot of control. As a manager (and this is especially true when you get into the outsourcing fiasco) you pay a set amount of money for a team to give you a specific product. The problem is that the employees you pay for are often unskilled and overworked. They’re even shared between multiple clients. That means the people you’re paying are working maybe a third of their time on your project. These circumstances just don’t make for a good product (or a good situation from a humanistic approach, but don’t get me started on that). So the problem is that there’s no trust in these relationships. Remote workers could leave their desk for 5–6 hours and you would never know. Doesn’t seem like something that could be solved by statistics, right? And yet, that’s exactly what people are doing. There are other variants, but my company uses a software called Worksmart. It tracks employees (what apps they’re working, how productive they’re being, etc) and shows how they’re doing in comparison to one another. They can see all of this, too. So if they see that statistically, Daniel has the most productive days, they can see what he’s doing and try to emulate them. The software uses metrics to track how everyone is doing. It’s solved a huge portion of the problems our CEO was first noticing. I use it (and so do all the rest of our workforce, including the CEO himself) and it’s incredibly helpful.
All problems come with an equall answer. Thats the science of maths, positive and negative go together to make something bigger( atomic bomb) stats are part of the matrix to get the equations right.
